text.p: Headlines from major national newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
EL PAIS
- Spain's government and Catalan president Jordi Pujol agree to merge Catalan electricity companies Fecsa, ENHER and Hidruna.

- Spain's military intelligence chief Javier Calderon testifies before judge in case investigating death of two ETA (Basque Homeland and Freedom) suspects in 1980s "dirty war" against Basque separatists.
EL MUNDO
- Bilbao's bishop offers to mediate peace talks with ETA and asks for repatriation of ETA prisoners to Basque country.
- Government will sell its whole 21 percent stake in Telefonica at the end of January 1997.
DIARIO 16
- Diario 16 celebrates 20 years of publication.
- Basque Nationalist Party says it is continuing contact with ETA to try to end violence.
ABC
- Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar has reduced number of his advisors to 27 while his predecessor Felipe Gonzalez had 43.
CINCO DIAS
- Spain's electricity group Endesa denies it plans to sell off its 80 percent stake in Viesgo.
- Stock market indices reach highs despite suspension of five electricity stocks.
- Bank of Spain governor Luis Angel Rojo warns against euphoric expectations that Spain will be among first members of European monetary union in 1999.
- Spain's transport companies will pass rise in gas prices onto customer.
EXPANSION
- Stock market value of main electricity companies has risen 400 billion pesetas in 12 days since talk emerged that Endesa would launch an offer for Sevillana and Fecsa.
- Economy ministry has launched investigation into profitability of pensions' collective savings schemes.
GACETA DE LOS NEGOCIOS
- Stock market value of electricity companies rises 225 billion pesetas in two days.
- Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato says budget adjustments will last two more years.
- BBV posts 20 percent increase in its group profit.
